articles.headline: As Yard Sales Boom in Hard Times, Sentiment Is First Thing to Go
articles.snippet: With people seeking cash in hard times, garage sales are flourishing so much that some cities are cracking down.
articles.abstract: With people seeking cash in hard times, garage sales are flourishing so much that some cities are cracking down.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANTECA, Calif.  As the classified ads put it, everything must go. Socks. Christmas ornaments. Microwave ovens. Three-year-old Marita Duarte’s tricycle was sold by her mother, Beatriz, to a stranger for $3 even as her daughter was riding it.

articles.headline: They’re Shocked, Shocked, About the Mess
articles.snippet: Like the boy who cried wolf, corporate and regulatory officials have issued a lot of hogwash over the years.
articles.abstract: Like the boy who cried wolf, corporate and regulatory officials have issued a lot of hogwash over the years.
articles.lead_paragraph: MY hypocrisy meter konked out last week.

articles.headline: So When Will Banks Give Loans?
articles.snippet: The banking industry’s dirty little secret is that it has no intention of using the bailout money to make new loans.
articles.abstract: The banking industry’s dirty little secret is that it has no intention of using the bailout money to make new loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Chase recently received $25 billion in federal funding. What effect will that have on the business side and will it change our strategic lending policy?”

articles.headline: Insurers Are Getting in Line for Piece of Federal Bailout
articles.snippet: The government considered extending the bailout to include insurance companies, and the auto industry stepped up efforts to secure a share of the money.
articles.abstract: The government considered extending the bailout to include insurance companies, and the auto industry stepped up efforts to secure a share of the money.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The chase for a piece of the Treasury Department’s $700 billion bailout program intensified Friday as the government considered extending it to include insurance companies as well as banks, and the auto industry stepped up efforts to secure a share of the money.
articles.byline: By Edmund L. Andrews and Eric Dash

articles.headline: The Broker Rebellion
articles.snippet: Caught in the middle of the credit squeeze and stock market downturn, some brokers are walking away from the big firms and going independent.
articles.abstract: Caught in the middle of the credit squeeze and stock market downturn, some brokers are walking away from the big firms and going independent.
articles.lead_paragraph: David B. Armstrong was proud for a long time to be part of Merrill Lynch’s thundering herd  the brokers in the storefronts and office buildings who are the face of Wall Street to many Americans.

articles.headline: Citadel Chief Denies Rumors of Trouble
articles.snippet: Kenneth C. Griffin held an emergency conference call that transfixed Wall Street, where some fear that troubled hedge funds might dump investments into the already-shaky markets.
articles.abstract: Kenneth C. Griffin held an emergency conference call that transfixed Wall Street, where some fear that troubled hedge funds might dump investments into the already-shaky markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: The hedge fund manager Kenneth C. Griffin christened his company Citadel  a name that conjures images of ancient strongholds.

articles.headline: Federal Aid Seen as Vital to a Merger in Detroit
articles.snippet: A possible merger of G.M. and Chrysler is said to appear to hinge on the U.S. government providing aid to support the deal.
articles.abstract: A possible merger of G.M. and Chrysler is said to appear to hinge on the U.S. government providing aid to support the deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  A possible merger of General Motors and Chrysler increasingly appears to hinge on federal aid, according to people with knowledge of the merger talks.

articles.headline: A Puzzle Over Prisoners as Iraqis Take Control
articles.snippet: The fate of the 17,000 people held by the U.S. in Iraq after the transition to full Iraqi sovereignty remains unclear.
articles.abstract: The fate of the 17,000 people held by the U.S. in Iraq after the transition to full Iraqi sovereignty remains unclear.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAMP BUCCA, Iraq  America’s largest detention facility is here in Iraq’s southern desert, and it sits at the center of one of the most complex debates in the transition from American military rule to full Iraqi sovereignty: what to do with the 5,000 Iraqi prisoners whom the United States military considers a threat to the hard-fought and still fragile calm in Iraq?

articles.headline: Some Currencies Plunge as Stocks Sink Worldwide
articles.snippet: The turmoil in currency markets has prompted talk of a coordinated intervention by leading industrial countries.
articles.abstract: The turmoil in currency markets has prompted talk of a coordinated intervention by leading industrial countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Fear that the financial crisis is infecting once-healthy economies created another white-knuckle day for investors Friday, causing stocks to tumble from Tokyo to New York.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: G.O.P. Senses Opportunities in Statehouse Races
articles.snippet: State lawmakers, unlike their counterparts in Congress, are not expecting a broad wave of Democratic victories.
articles.abstract: State lawmakers, unlike their counterparts in Congress, are not expecting a broad wave of Democratic victories.
articles.lead_paragraph: Unlike their counterparts in Congress, who are expecting a wave of Democratic Party victories on Election Day, lawmakers in statehouses across the country are finding there are as many opportunities for Republicans as Democrats.

articles.headline: But Have We Learned Enough?
articles.snippet: Understanding the Great Depression and avoiding another one are two different things.
articles.abstract: Understanding the Great Depression and avoiding another one are two different things.
articles.lead_paragraph: LIKE most economists, those at the International Monetary Fund are lowering their growth forecasts. The financial turmoil gripping Wall Street will probably spill over onto every other street in America. Most likely, current job losses are only the tip of an ugly iceberg.

articles.headline: General Motors, Driven to the Brink
articles.snippet: G.M., like other American automakers, tied its fortunes to the S.U.V., a product line that may be the industry’s undoing.
articles.abstract: G.M., like other American automakers, tied its fortunes to the S.U.V., a product line that may be the industry’s undoing.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN late May, senior executives at General Motors confronted a decision that few thought they would ever face: whether to continue developing the next generation of one of the most successful products in G.M.’s 100-year history  the full-size sport utility vehicle  or to punt the program entirely.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: Moscow’s Mayor Exports Russia’s New Nationalism
articles.snippet: Yuri M. Luzhkov has spent hundreds of millions of dollars over the last decade to support ethnic Russians and stoke separatism in nations on Russia’s borders.
articles.abstract: Yuri M. Luzhkov has spent hundreds of millions of dollars over the last decade to support ethnic Russians and stoke separatism in nations on Russia’s borders.
articles.lead_paragraph: TSKHINVALI, Georgia  On a clearing in this disputed city, where enemy homes were bulldozed after the conflict in August, Mayor Yuri M. Luzhkov promised this month to build a new neighborhood for the South Ossetian separatists here.

articles.headline: Democrats See Risk and Reward if Party Sweeps
articles.snippet: Republicans, for their part, are warning voters about unchecked one-party government and urging them to deny Democrats unfettered control.
articles.abstract: Republicans, for their part, are warning voters about unchecked one-party government and urging them to deny Democrats unfettered control.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The possibility of a victory by Senator Barack Obama combined with significant Congressional gains by his party could give Democrats extraordinary muscle to pursue an ambitious agenda on health care, taxes, union rights, energy and national security.
articles.byline: By Carl Hulse and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: In Age of Impatience, Cutting PC Start Time
articles.snippet: The world’s major PC makers plan to introduce a new generation of quick-start computers.
articles.abstract: The world’s major PC makers plan to introduce a new generation of quick-start computers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  It is the black hole of the digital age  the three minutes it can take for your computer to boot up, when there is nothing to do but wait, and wait, and wait some more before you can log on and begin multitasking at hyper-speed.
articles.byline: By Matt Richtel and Ashlee Vance

articles.headline: Spending Stalls and Businesses Slash U.S. Jobs
articles.snippet: As the financial crisis cuts demand for American goods and services, the workers who produce them are losing their jobs by the tens of thousands.
articles.abstract: As the financial crisis cuts demand for American goods and services, the workers who produce them are losing their jobs by the tens of thousands.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the financial crisis crimps demand for American goods and services, the workers who produce them are losing their jobs by the tens of thousands.

articles.headline: Campaign Gravy Train at an End
articles.snippet: For the last few months, local stations, and to some degree networks, have been frolicking in money spent by the presidential campaigns.
articles.abstract: For the last few months, local stations, and to some degree networks, have been frolicking in money spent by the presidential campaigns.
articles.lead_paragraph: Let’s be honest. As much as we are looking forward to Nov. 4, when a historic and riveting presidential campaign will finally reach a verdict, it’s going to take more than a few aspirin and a nap to get rid of the hangover we will feel the next day.

articles.headline: Global Financial Troubles Reaching Into Gulf States
articles.snippet: Major oil-producing countries had seemed to be insulated from the crisis shaking the foundations of the international financial system.
articles.abstract: Major oil-producing countries had seemed to be insulated from the crisis shaking the foundations of the international financial system.
articles.lead_paragraph: The global financial crisis extended its reach into the Persian Gulf states on Sunday, as Kuwait suspended trading in shares of a major bank and the Saudi authorities announced a plan to help citizens receive credit.

articles.headline: Huffington and Brown: Paths Intertwine in the Blog Thicket
articles.snippet: Although they run competing Web sites, Tina Brown and Arianna Huffington are friends.
articles.abstract: Although they run competing Web sites, Tina Brown and Arianna Huffington are friends.
articles.lead_paragraph: After Tina Brown’s signature Talk Magazine closed in 2001, she reached out to an old friend for support: Arianna Huffington.

articles.headline: Quickly Vetted, Treatment Is Offered to Patients
articles.snippet: The F.D.A. regularly allows devices to market after only cursory review and without clear evidence they help.
articles.abstract: The F.D.A. regularly allows devices to market after only cursory review and without clear evidence they help.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a surgeon removed a cancerous lump from Karen Medlock’s breast in November, he recommended radiation, a routine next step meant to keep cancer from recurring.

articles.headline: To Survive, Net Start-Ups Slow Their Metabolism
articles.snippet: To preserve cash during the current downturn, many tech start-ups are rushing to lay off employees and cut expenses.
articles.abstract: To preserve cash during the current downturn, many tech start-ups are rushing to lay off employees and cut expenses.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Silicon Valley has always been a land of big, bold dreams. In the first Internet boom its start-ups either grew fast or died trying, sometimes spectacularly. The casualties of the bust, like Pets.com and Webvan, became legendary.
articles.byline: By Brad Stone and Claire Cain Miller

articles.headline: End of Battle Centers on Turf Bush Carried
articles.snippet: Senators John McCain and Barack Obama are spending time in states once solid for the Republican Party, a sign of Mr. McCain’s dire position in the final week.
articles.abstract: Senators John McCain and Barack Obama are spending time in states once solid for the Republican Party, a sign of Mr. McCain’s dire position in the final week.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator John McCain and Senator Barack Obama are heading into the final week of the presidential campaign planning to spend nearly all their time in states that President Bush won last time, testimony to the increasingly dire position of Mr. McCain and his party as Election Day approaches.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Forecasters Race to Call the Bottom to the Market
articles.snippet: Just as financial analysts competed for attention on the way up, the pundit class seems compelled to out-gloom the next guy.
articles.abstract: Just as financial analysts competed for attention on the way up, the pundit class seems compelled to out-gloom the next guy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Could the Dow reach 7,000? 700? Seven?

articles.headline: Democrats in Steel Country See Color, and Beyond It
articles.snippet: John McCain hopes for an opening in Pennsylvania, where race talk is sometimes submerged, sometimes open.
articles.abstract: John McCain hopes for an opening in Pennsylvania, where race talk is sometimes submerged, sometimes open.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALIQUIPPA, Pa.  Voting for the black man does not come easy to Nick Piroli. He is the first to admit that.

articles.headline: David Geffen Makes a Sudden Exit
articles.snippet: The DreamWorks executive engineered some of Hollywood’s most breathtaking deals and transitions for nearly 40 years.
articles.abstract: The DreamWorks executive engineered some of Hollywood’s most breathtaking deals and transitions for nearly 40 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: UNIVERSAL CITY, Calif.  As of last week, David Geffen’s phone line at DreamWorks SKG headquarters here was still live. But some people were already struggling to accept that he would no longer be part of the movie company he had helped build.

articles.headline: Officials Say U.S. Killed an Iraqi in Raid in Syria
articles.snippet: The operation appeared to reflect an effort by the Bush administration to find a way to attack militants even beyond the borders of Iraq and Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: The operation appeared to reflect an effort by the Bush administration to find a way to attack militants even beyond the borders of Iraq and Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  A raid into Syria on Sunday was carried out by American Special Operations forces who killed an Iraqi militant responsible for running weapons, money and foreign fighters across the border into Iraq, American officials said Monday.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Thom Shanker
